primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in a world dominated by the 'gloom of sin and grief' by sending His Son as the Lamb to take away the sin of the world and deliver humanity from bondage.

tekstueel_bewijs: God's heart is revealed; his heart for those who suffer.
The Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.
He was pleased to pierce that gloom.

object.identificatie: Deliverance/Taking away sin/Restoration of the Kingdom
tekstueel_bewijs: The powerful sign of the Lord’s deliverance.
The sin of the world taken away in the self-offering of the Son of God.
He who sent me to baptize with water said to me...
As God the Father spoke to John the Baptist, so he speaks to us.

ontvanger.identificatie: The World / The Hearer / The Suffering
tekstueel_bewijs: For us gave up his dying breath.
Releases his people from every bond.

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / John the Baptist (as witness)
tekstueel_bewijs: I saw the Spirit descend as a dove.
John the Baptist is the model... he pointed away from himself to Jesus.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, Herod, Human Perversity, 'The Worm'
tekstueel_bewijs: There is a worm eating away at the core of things.
The gloom of sin and grief separates us.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described as a power that requires 'deliverance' rather than just forgiveness; it is an ontological 'worm' at the core of reality.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The response of the believer to the epiphany: taking up the cross and following Jesus into the dark places of the world.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Disciples
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is a direct result of the primary program (soteriology). The epiphany of the Lamb causes the disciples to follow.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God the Father → Deliverance → The World

voorbeelden_god_subject: The Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.
He was pleased to pierce that gloom.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We determine to face the truth about ourselves.

voorbeelden: We have a job to do.
Our willingness to enter into judgment.
We don’t like it, we don’t want it.
John himself did not know the answer until it was told him by God.
We need a power from outside this realm.
The powerful sign of the Lord’s deliverance.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human inability (lack of power) and the necessity of an external power (God's Pouvoir) to effect change.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (the gloom of the world) to the realization that ~S1 (human effort/millennium talk) is insufficient, finally resolving in S1 (The Lamb's sacrifice).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'Subject-switch': Christ takes the place of the sinner (Substitution).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; sin is treated as a cosmic power, not just a mistake.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God is the primary actor, and the human role is defined by receiving and witnessing to an external deliverance.

indicatoren_moralisme.indicator: Minor call to 'do a job' regarding education.
indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: We have a job to do, in the church; we need more crash courses.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as the subject of active verbs regarding salvation.
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.
It should have been me, up there; it should have been you; but it was not. It was him.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: John the Baptist is used as a model, but specifically as a model of 'pointing away from self,' which subverts traditional exemplarism.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: John is a 'witness' to God's action, not a hero to be emulated for his own virtues.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; shifting focus from self-improvement to the 'Lamb'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation; God does the work, man receives the benefit.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'fading light of Christmas' to the 'Cross' is perfectly integrated into the actantial movement.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The great High Priest has become the sacrifice... in our place.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit identifies the Son to the witness; the Spirit 'remains' on the Subject (Jesus).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a 'worm' and 'bondage' that humans cannot escape alone.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the Subject of the primary narrative program. The hearer is correctly positioned as the Receiver of the Object (Deliverance).

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly high on Savoir (knowing the definitions of Lamb).
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current focus on Pouvoir (God's power).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The explanation of Exodus 12 is excellent for Savoir-faire.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (The Lamb) precedes and enables Ethics (Taking up the cross).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-oriented preaching. It avoids the trap of 'exemplarism' by making the biblical witness (John) a pointer to the true Subject (Jesus).

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Christmas tree' anecdote, Greimas shows that the anecdote serves to establish the 'Axis of Desire' for a world that doesn't want to fast.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains what 'Lamb' meant in 30 AD; semiotics shows how 'Lamb' functions as the Subject that resolves the 'Opponent' of sin in the hearer's present reality.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'taking down of decorations' is a modal shift from Vouloir (wanting flowers) to Devoir/Pouvoir (accepting the Cross).

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Rutledge Rule' perfectly.
